instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00239: What is 820-00239? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT: What is PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT? PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT is a power rail that powers the LED light in the screen of the device that allows you to see what is on the screen. When this is low or missing, the screen will be dim..
definitions.LCDBKLT_EN_L: What is LCDBKLT_EN_L? This signal enables the backlight when it is low.  _L means the signal asserts itself when the voltage is low. This signal needs to be low to enable backlight. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liqued damage and no backlight system turns on
threads.message:
hi all.
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> came in liqued damage
only spot i was able to find is direct on the lcd connector

using a differnt lcd and connector does not make a differnce.

keyboard and touch bar gives light and responds to pressing a button or touchbar
fan spins after few minutes (to long imo)

<SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> 0.155volt   1.130 DIODE READING
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT_R</SIGNAL> 13.06v
<SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_EN_L</SIGNAL> 12.95v
<RESISTOR>R8402</RESISTOR> 63.8kohm
<RESISTOR>R8401</RESISTOR> 80.8kohm

my gues atm is lcd is not reconized/seen

but any help is welkom alot :)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liqued damage and no backlight system turns on
threads.message: Do you have an image is the #1 thing of course.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liqued damage and no backlight system turns on
threads.message:
cant see anything duke, does not mather wat lcd i use (have 2 atm ) dont have a second MacBook so cant test that :(

but icant see anything when i shine a light i also dont see like the fluid moving in the screen

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liqued damage and no backlight system turns on
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0SW_LCD</SIGNAL> present? LCD must be plugged in and it could only be a pulse on startup.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liqued damage and no backlight system turns on
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0SW_LCD</SIGNAL> i get pulse of 5.15V at startup takes about 6 or 7 second and then he gives the pulse

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liqued damage and no backlight system turns on
threads.message: So it is not seeing the LCD. Check all caps and traces in the eDP lines to the LCD connector.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liqued damage and no backlight system turns on
threads.message:
would seeing the lcd mean it is a stable volt of 5V?
and would no pulse at all say (so really nothing) mean there is no power going treu the line (kinda like a short)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liqued damage and no backlight system turns on
threads.message: It should see a stable 5V to power the display's circuitry, follow dukes advice

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liqued damage and no backlight system turns on
threads.message: It pulses the 5V shortly and if there is no LCD detected it will shut down again. LCD EDID detection is done through <SIGNAL>EDP_INT_AUX</SIGNAL> lines, check those first as they are also the corner of the connector and easily fucked.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liqued damage and no backlight system turns on
threads.message:
here is a part of where i feel like a dumbo.

i have these 2 lines that have <SIGNAL>EDP_INT_AUX</SIGNAL> in it. both go from <CHIP>U0500</CHIP> to the connector only passing true <RESISTOR>R8503</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R8502</RESISTOR> (both no stuf)

<SIGNAL>EDP_INT_AUX_N</SIGNAL> 0.004 diode (i think this one is fucked so i measured at the probe points and get the same)
<SIGNAL>EDP_INT_AUX_P</SIGNAL> 0.203 diode

my gues is a bad connector even if it looks good :(

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liqued damage and no backlight system turns on
threads.message: Display connectors often go bad while looking pristine after being hit by liquid, I'd say give it a try

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liqued damage and no backlight system turns on
threads.message:
nope stil short..... thats not good...

<SIGNAL>EDP_INT_AUX_N</SIGNAL> only removed connector and cleaned pads. did not replace
measured diode 0.004 and solid beep

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liqued damage and no backlight system turns on
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R8502</RESISTOR>/03 are pull ups and not pass through!

The only places where these signals go are the connector and CPU. I guess now you know this thing is fucked.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liqued damage and no backlight system turns on
threads.message:
yup, just as i thought this is no good :)

so this can be marked as closed its a dead pos....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liqued damage and no backlight system turns on
threads.message: A quick question as I have the same problem as above, does the <SIGNAL>EDP_INT_AUX_N</SIGNAL> have a stable voltage that comes from the CPU? and if so does anyone know what this voltage is?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liqued damage and no backlight system turns on
threads.message: No, it is a data line and make a new thread for further support.
